 I reject these arguments on two levels:
 
 First, your use of the word 'always' troubles me greatly. How many billions of years into the past does your assertion extend? We have no evidence to support the concept of good and evil existing for more than a tiny fraction of time, and considerable evidence to support the existence of our ancestors for much, much longer than that.
 
 Secondly, even if we are trying to grasp or define something external to our individual selves, that does not imply its objectivity or independent existence. This may seem like an impossible statement, but I will justify it in due course.
 
 To evidence, then:
 
 Evolution (the observation of its occurrence, not the theory) demonstrates that the concept of 'success' and 'failure' exists outside of the human mind. A successful organism makes more of itself; an unsuccessful one disappears. The process embodies success and failure, regardless of any individual organism's awareness of it. 
 
 From that one can extrapolate definitions of beneficial and harmful. However, they may still be applied at a number of levels in often contradictory fashion. An elephant's teeth, for example, are eventually ground down to the root, starving to death an animal often still perfectly capable of reproduction. Harmful for the survival of the individual, but ultimately beneficial for the continuation of the genes it contains. On another level you have humans, who have enjoyed immense success as a species, possibly to the fatal detriment of the biosphere that supports them.
 
 What picture of Good and Evil do we paint on such a canvas?
 
 First, we can very quickly define 'good' or 'bad' behaviour in terms of the benefit or harm it causes, pausing to note that good and bad are indeed adjectives we apply to categorise actions. 
 
 But that definition is inextricably bound to the level of abstraction at which you are measuring benefit or harm. An act which benefits an individual may harm other individuals, or society as a whole, or even the whole planet. Contrarywise, an act which benefits society may harm an individual - or even all individuals.
 
 From there, we can appreciate that what at first glance appears to be a historical struggle to define 'objective' good and evil is better explained as our progressively more sophisticated social intellect coming to grips with higher levels of abstraction of 'success', 'failure', 'benefit' and 'harm', and seeking the optimum balance.
 
 It's obvious (and marvellous) that pure selfish bean-counting individualism is less successful than a degree of commitment and cooperation. But we can also see that higher levels of abstraction are not necessarily better either - and this is where I return to the issue of objectivity. 
 
 Objective Good and Evil (note capitals) would necessarily occupy the highest possible level of abstraction. But the human cost of Communism as pursued in the Soviet Union clearly shows the flaw in placing 'the good of' highly abstract concepts like society or ideology entirely before 'the good of' individuals. The endless strife in the middle east is an equally poignant illustration of what happens when people get it into their heads that 'the greater good' is all that matters.
 
 In most modern cultures, when defining morality, we seek to balance benefit and harm to individuals with that caused to society, the species and the biosphere. Are we seeking to arrive at some objective definition? Not at all; whatever conclusion we reach (or more likely orbit like a strange attractor), it is defined by the tension between our desires, our nature and our circumstances. Were our success due to less individualistic behaviour, as in the ant kingdom, our morals would be far different than they are. Were selfishness inherently more successful, they would be different again. In straightened circumstances, we adopt different social mores than in more comfortable times.
 
 Good and Evil, then, are terms we use to describe behaviour in the context of our chosen balance between individualism, social obligation and our responsibility to the wider world. They are defined by that balance, and as a consequence could not have existed beforehand. And although they are outside us as individuals, they are inextricably linked with our natures, belonging as they do to no other entity or creature.

Hi all;
 
 Debates about good, evil, and human morality are fun, aren't they? Especially as they never seem to get resolved, one way or another.
 
 A couple of points that always arise, as they have done in this thread:--
 
 A/ There are events that are labelled 'evil', like volcanic eruptions, or 'good', like a big catch of fish, that are neither 'good' nor 'evil' in moral terms. This has already been pointed out and should not be brought up again in this thread except as a rejoinder to those who hold the position that the source of all 'good' is their notion of an absolute, "god", one who is in complete and perfect control of all things, of each and every event in the universe. For such believers the terms 'good' and 'evil' are rendered meaningless and absurd, and so cease to exist. Or should, rationally. They generally are, and are replaced by 'fate', 'kismet', 'fortune', 'pre-destination/grace', and in modern materialistic terms, 'mechanical/genetic determinism'.
 
 B/ The distinction between relative morality and absolute morality. Everyone agrees to the existence of relative, that is say, 'local', separation of thoughts, goals, desires, beliefs, values, and above all, actions/behaviours, into categories described as [using the adjectives of] 'good', 'evil', their cognates, and any combination of them to shade and classify by degrees, on what appears to be an open-ended continuum. Relative morality, aside from 'good wars', and whatnot, has, at some time or place, in some society or other, found that everything from cannibalism to burning babies alive were 'good' behaviours. This relative, local morality is hardly more than custom and zeitgeist, and is hardly worth debating.
 
 This leaves us with the issue of absolute morality; that is, a morality in which good and evil exist without any people to determine which is which, a morality that is independent of human definition. Does it or does it not exist? If it does, can it be discovered? 
 
 If you begin with the premise, "Such absolute morality does not exist.", there is hardly any point in arguing further, since you cannot prove a negative proposition/opinion through mental argumentation/reasoning alone, but only with physical, empirical, sensory observation of an absence or contradictory fact. And then only in the relative, local sense, and that will never prove any 'a priori' absolute, universal position in any case. This has, of course, been pointed out earlier in the thread. Elephants in the room, dragons in the garage, and all that.
 
 So that leaves only those who believe that an absolute moral arbiter or criterion exists that is independent of human definition and human belief in it. Can such believers present evidence, from logic or from empirical observation or from any combination of the two, that supports this positive premise of universal, independently-existing, non-corporeal entities (nouns) named 'good' and 'evil', or not? And, if they exist as a 'state', (as has been posited by one poster, and which I take him to mean a \'condition or mode of being, existing\', what rational or empirical evidence exists to substantiate that claim?
 
 These are not rhetorical questions. I have wasted many any idle hour asking them of myself, but have not yet found a truly satisfactory answer. Hope to hear from someone with more insight than myself.
